title.narrative: Efficient water management in Iraq switching to climate smart agriculture: capacity building and knowledge development

participating-org.narrative: IHE Delft Institute for Water Education
International Centre for development oriented Research in Agriculture

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: @OKP-IRAQ-104278 Project has a new paper jointly written and published in Water MDPI
A 3-day (online) workshop workshop organsied by university of Mosul about Agro-hydrology rain water harvesting
A new published paper: Efficient water management in Iraq switching to climate smart agriculture: capacity building and knowledge development
A workshop at university of Anbar about Agro-hydrology and Crop production

Results for Output 2 during the Workshop 8-12 November 2021 in Wageningen: Establishing partnerships and Strengthening capacities in efficient water management & Climate smart agriculture and institutional strengthening at six universities in Iraq
Results for Output 5 during the Workshop 8-12 November 2021 in Wageningen:
The first jointly written research article has been published: Water Quality, Availability, and Uses in Rural Communities in the Kurdistan Region, Iraq
Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

comment.narrative: **At least 12 teaching staff from 6 universities (6** **male, 6 female) have gained quantitative and** **relevant** **knowledge** **and skills** **from short** **training courses, to offer revised study programmes** **(A.E.3)**

28-04-2021: 11 staff trained in 2020 ("Making education Work"). These 11 will interact with colleagues in 2020. | 28-04-2021: 12 staff (2 per university) started course on "making education work", of which 11 completed the course in 2020
28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
6 (universities) + 6 (Water directorates in 6 cities)+ 6 Agriculture directorates+ 2 ministries of HE in KRG & GoI)

comment.narrative: 29-04-2021: Assessments conducted in 2020. Each university regards "minority" in distinct ways, depending on geography, religion, religious denomination, nationality or ethnicity.

title.narrative: A.O.11. Number of organisations with policies and procedures to ensure an environment which is gender sensitive

comment.narrative: 29-04-2021: Gender/inclusivity assessments conducted at 6 universities in 2020.
Partners could increase this up to 9 in total (all partners of the consortium)

title.narrative: A.O.6. Number of facilities established/strengthened

comment.narrative: Improve training facilities in the 6 universities: Starting the Knowledge transfer facilities (KTF) in each University

title.narrative: A.S.2. Number of MoUs or other types of collaboration agreements signed (education, private, public, surrounding community)

comment.narrative: 03-05-2021: All universities have (very variable in number) collaboration agreements with a variety of other organisations (e.g. Salahaddin UE has reported 300). No new ones have been signed as a direct result of the project.
Calculation of total 18 MoUs: the 6 Iraqi universities sign MoU with the 3 NL knowledge institutes.

title.narrative: A.O.8. % of women of teaching staff of faculty/department

Partners still need to indicate the % women staff

title.narrative: A.S.4. Number of SMEs supported

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: Training of farmers delayed to 2021

Iraqis informed us they organise trainings for the local farmers at least 4 times a year. In each training at least 50 farmer attend, so within 1 year 200 farmers will be trained. So, in 5 years, 1000 farmers will be trained in each city. The total from the 6 universities (6 cities) will be 6000 farmers.

B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered | 28-04-2021: The project was not yet started

28-04-2021: Participants in 5 different virtual trainings: 11 on "making education work" (iCRA-Output 1); 12 on "making research work" (iCRA-Output 2); 8 on "Water productivity and water accounting" (IHE - Output 3); 6 on "Rain water harvesting (WUR-Output 3); and 7 on "Agrohydrology and crop production" (WUR-Output 3).

Iraqis informed us they organise trainings for the local farmers at least 4 times a year. In each training at least 50 farmer attend, so within 1 year 200 farmers will be trained. So, in 5 years, 1000 farmers will be trained in each city. The total from the 6 universities (6 cities) will be 6000 farmers. Throughout the LF and for a number of the outputs the first year 12 staff will be trained – 2 lecturers per university, I gather. This number grows to 18 at the end of the project.
**36 scholarship holders from 6 Universities, including 15 women, have successfully completed short training courses, and one person has successfully completed an MSc programme. **

title.narrative: B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: Assessments conducted in 2020; strategies will be completed in 2021.
28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
The six universities have mainstreamed gender in the improved organisational policies, culminating in gender implementation plans and strategies

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: Criteria not yet evaluated. Training programmes completed at end of 2020
28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
200 alumni state that they have applied in their workplace the knowledge and skills gained from the interventions by 5 years after project completion

title.narrative: B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: Indicator not evaluated
- 6 Iraqi Universities have revised institutional mechanisms for quality assurance (A.O.3)

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: Project is working with 6 public universities. Staff from all 6 attended virtual trainings in 2020.
**6 Iraqi organizations have been strengthened by individual and/or group training. **

title.narrative: B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: Satisfaction levels for each course were evaluated independently using different criteria and scales. In general, satisfaction levels were high.

Satisfaction of participants was not indicated. Partners could work on this after the end of the training to have feedback from the participants. Especially from **36 scholarship holders from 6 Universities, including 15 women, have successfully completed short training courses. **

title.narrative: B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: all course participants still currently employed by the universities
At least 60 (30 male; 30 female), graduates from the 6 participating universities are employed or self employed by 1 year after graduating

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: indicator not formally evaluated. most participants on courses stated that content was relevant to them

No mention of post-training questionnaire to find out the effectiveness of knowledge presented. Partners need to demonstrate this. **At least 12 teaching staff from 6 universities (6** **male, 6 female) have gained quantitative and** **relevant** **knowledge** **and skills** **from short** **training courses, to offer revised study programmes**

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 28-04-2021: In 2019 no trainings were delivered
28-04-2021: no information available
100 alumni have been promoted to more strategic positions within their own organisation or other organisation by 5 years after project end

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: All 6 universities conducted a gender/minority inclusiveness assessment, evaluating organisational structure, policies, plans and activities. Developed plans will be implemented in 2021.
